title: To use GitHub API from Go you can use
github.com/google/go-github
a
http://github.com/google/go-github
package. GitHub, like many other sites, uses OAuth 2.0 protocol for authentication. There are few packages for Go that implement OAuth. This article describes how to use
golang.org/x/oauth2
a
http://golang.org/x/oauth2
package. If you prefer to read code, read
this sample
a
https://github.com/kjk/kjkpub/blob/master/go/github_sample/sample_1.go

title: Short intro to OAuth for GitHub

inline_content.Text: Short intro to OAuth for GitHub

title: To access private info about the user via the API in your web app you need to authenticate your app against GitHub website.

inline_content.Text: To access private info about the user via the API in your web app you need to authenticate your app against GitHub website.

title: First, you need to
register your application with GitHub
a
https://github.com/settings/applications

(under Developer applications). You provide description of the app, including a callback url (we’ll get back to that). GitHub creates client id and client secret that you’ll need to provide to OAuth libraries (and keep them secret).

inline_content.Text: (under Developer applications). You provide description of the app, including a callback url (we’ll get back to that). GitHub creates client id and client secret that you’ll need to provide to OAuth libraries (and keep them secret).

title: the user is on your website and clicks “login with GitHub” link

inline_content.Text: the user is on your website and clicks “login with GitHub” link

title: you redirect the user to GitHub’s authorization page. In that url you specify desired access level and a random secret

inline_content.Text: you redirect the user to GitHub’s authorization page. In that url you specify desired access level and a random secret

title: the user authorizes your app by clicking on a link

inline_content.Text: the user authorizes your app by clicking on a link

title: GitHub redirects to a callback url on your website (which you provided when registering the app with GitHub)

inline_content.Text: GitHub redirects to a callback url on your website (which you provided when registering the app with GitHub)

title: in the url handler, extract “secret” and “code” args

inline_content.Text: in the url handler, extract “secret” and “code” args

title: you have to check that the secret is the same as the one you sent to GitHub (security measure that prevents forgery)

inline_content.Text: you have to check that the secret is the same as the one you sent to GitHub (security measure that prevents forgery)

title: you call another GitHub url to exchange code for access token

inline_content.Text: you call another GitHub url to exchange code for access token

title: Access token is what you use to authenticate your API calls.

inline_content.Text: Access token is what you use to authenticate your API calls.

title: You define callback url when you register the app. This is a problem for testing, because your app might use different hosts for development or production. One option is to create different apps for testing and production, with different callback urls. OAuth protocol allows providing callback url as an argument when calling authorization page (and oauth2 library allows setting it as
oauth2.Config.RedirectURL
c
) but GitHub
has restrictions
a
https://developer.github.com/v3/oauth/#redirect-urls
and doesn’t allow changing host.

inline_content.Text: You define callback url when you register the app. This is a problem for testing, because your app might use different hosts for development or production. One option is to create different apps for testing and production, with different callback urls. inline_content.Text: In the handler for /login url, redirect to GitHub’s authorization page:

title: GitHub will show authorization page to your user. If the user authorizes your app, GitHub will re-direct to OAuth callback. Here’s how you can turn it into a token, token into http client and use that client to list GitHub information about user:

inline_content.Text: GitHub will show authorization page to your user. If the user authorizes your app, GitHub will re-direct to OAuth callback. Here’s how you can turn it into a token, token into http client and use that client to list GitHub information about user:

title: And finally this is how you tie everything together:

inline_content.Text: And finally this is how you tie everything together:

title:
func main() {
    http.HandleFunc("/", handleMain)
    http.HandleFunc("/login", handleGitHubLogin)
    http.HandleFunc("/github_oauth_cb", handleGitHubCallback)
    fmt.Print("Started running on http://127.0.0.1:7000\n")
    fmt.Println(http.ListenAndServe(":7000", nil))
}

content_resolved.code:
func main() {
    http.HandleFunc("/", handleMain)
    http.HandleFunc("/login", handleGitHubLogin)
    http.HandleFunc("/github_oauth_cb", handleGitHubCallback)
    fmt.Print("Started running on http://127.0.0.1:7000\n")
    fmt.Println(http.ListenAndServe(":7000", nil))
}

title: If you want to access someone else’s GitHub info, you need to authorize your app with GitHub as described above. If you want to access your own account, you can generate a
personal access token
a
https://github.com/settings/applications#personal-access-tokens
. Here’s how to do it:
